awd_titl_txt: Improving Mechatronics Education by Pairing Mechatronics Courses with General Education Math and Science Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
By 2024, in the area surrounding Roane State Community College, employment in electrical and electronics repair of commercial and industrial equipment is expected to increase by five percent. In contrast, the national growth rate is only two percent. Regional employers report that they have difficulty finding "business-oriented" or "well-rounded" technicians to fill their positions.  In particular, many candidates do not have the necessary knowledge, skills and abilities, such as critical thinking, applied knowledge, and complex problem-solving skills. Based on  a recent survey of employers, defining and solving problems, particularly numerical problems, and thinking critically were among recent graduates' weakest skills. To better meet industry needs for a highly-skilled technical workforce, this project will pair mechatronics courses with general education courses in math and science.  The general education courses will be enhanced with mechatronics-related problems and examples, thus providing a context that is relevant to the students' career goals.  Local area employers will be integrally involved in course development and provide examples of complex mechatronics issues that can be incorporated into problem-based learning scenarios within the courses.  It is expected that these paired courses will result in mechatronics graduates who are better prepared both academically and technically for work in mechatronics fields. 

Roane State Community College aims to improve the technical skills of mechatronics students by designing and implementing three co-requisite course pairs.  Each course pair will include a mechatronics course and one of the following: (a) a general education math course, (b) a learning support (developmental) math course, or (c) a general education science course. The project expects that these curricular changes will increase students' attainment of related learning outcomes, the number of students completing the general education core courses and programs, and employer satisfaction with graduates' knowledge, skills, and abilities. The co-requisite course pairs may provide replicable examples for enhancing mechatronics education at other institutions. In addition, the process used to develop this co-requisite model for teaching general education and mechatronics may be extended to other career-technical areas at Roane State Community College and at other colleges and universities. This project is expected to increase the degree completion rate of first-generation students for whom math and general education courses often pose a major hurdle to degree attainment. Because both faculty and industry partners will be involved in the development of the co-requisite courses, graduates of the program should be better prepared to meet employer expectations for mechatronics technicians in the workplace. Furthermore, the implementation plan and training materials could be adapted to co-requisite pairings in other post-secondary STEM education programs.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the Co-Req Mech grant, Roane State Community College aimed to improve the technical skills of mechatronics students by designing and implementing two co-requisite course pairs. Each course pair included a mechatronics course and one of the following: (a) a general education math course or (b) a general education science course. The assignments and activities students completed in their general education courses directly related to the concepts, assignments, and activities they saw in their mechatronics courses. General education faculty members worked closely with technical faculty members and representatives from local industry to create a contextualized curriculum that complements the mechatronics program and is specifically designed to help mechatronics students prepare for future courses and employment in their desired field. The goal was to enhance students' understanding of the theoretical concepts while providing contextualized applications for the topics generally covered in the general education course. Faculty created problem-based learning activities to allow the students to gain knowledge and skills by working for an extended period to investigate and respond to authentic, engaging, and complex questions, problems, or challenges that come from real-world issues faced by those working in the industry.

The senior faculty who made up the grant team expected these curricular changes to increase students' attainment of related learning outcomes, the number of students completing the general education core courses and programs, and employer satisfaction with graduates' knowledge, skills, and abilities. There was improvement across the board—most notably, the retention of mechatronics students from their first to second year increased from 38% to 67% and the rate of students graduating within 3 years increased from 38% to 67%. The data from the 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 cohorts will be available in 2025 and 2026, respectively.

Students saw connections between their general education course and the paired mechatronics course. One mechatronics student enrolled simultaneously in the contextualized general education math course and a process controls course reflected on the math/mech course pairing: “I like that the pairing made the math course more relevant with what I am going to this college for.”  Another mechatronics student enrolled in the contextualized general education physics course and a mechanics and machine elements course observed that the students were “Learning the same things from two different viewpoints.”

Other student survey responses included:

  • “I could use the same skills in both [classes].”
  • “Being able to apply math to motor controls and understanding and having the math knowledge [is] useful.”
  • “I noticed [connections between] algebraic equations such as calculating the voltage of a 3-phase motor and frequency of a motor.”
  • “The professors explained everything very well and explained how they connected.”
  • “You can use what you learned from one class to help with the other.”
  • “They were mostly the same course content wise. Both instructors had [different] strengths and weaknesses.”

During one pilot course, 63% of the students chose “strongly agree” when asked if the math instructor made connections to their mechatronics course work; the remaining students chose “agree.” Similarly, 50% of the participating students chose “strongly agree” when asked if the physics instructor made connections to their mechatronics coursework while the remaining 50% chose “agree.”

The activities created in conjunction with this project are available through ATE Connect, on the Co-Req Mech microsite.

Throughout the life of the grant, faculty from other general education disciplines have discussed and considered ways to contextualize their courses for the Mechatronics AAS degree. Both Composition 1 and Speech are required for the students to earn their associate degree and would be prime candidates for the next phase of contextualization.
